Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Semantic Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Semantic Computing (SC) is an emerging field that addresses computing technologies which allow users to search, create, manipulate and connect computational resources. The research efforts will be anchored by the University of California-Irvine as the lead institution, partnered with the University of California-Los Angeles and the University of California-San Diego.

Semantic Computing includes the computing technologies (e.g., artificial intelligence, natural language, software engineering, data and knowledge engineering, computer systems, signal processing, etc.), and their interactions, that may be used to extract or process computational content and descriptions. The proposed I/UCRC will focus on providing technologies that lead to a Semantic Problem Solving (SPS) network where distributed resources can be easily connected based on semantics for the purpose of problem solving. While some areas of Semantic Computing have appeared as isolated pieces in individual disciplines, Semantic Computing glues these pieces together into an integrated theme with synergetic interactions. It addresses not only the analysis and transformation of signals (e.g., pixels, words) into useful information, but also how such information can be accessed and used to synthesize new signals. The three proposed campuses have complementary areas of strength and have emphasized different aspects of Semantic Computing systems. All participating faculty are prominent researchers in one or more areas related to Semantic Computing.

The technologies developed by the proposed I/UCRC may support new inter-connectivity that has not been realized by the Internet today. It therefore may facilitate the transition of the Internet into Web 3.0 and stimulate new business models for a better economy that everyone can benefit. The technologies developed by the proposed I/UCRC will be delivered to the public via the Internet, and the PIs expect to create broader impacts in areas other than the five selected. The five areas are chosen as they characterize different aspects of problem solving, e.g., creativity (IT, entertainment), learning (education) and decision making (health, finance), which are applicable to many other areas such as manufacturing, science, engineering, and the humanities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semantic Computing (SC) is an emerging field that addresses computing technologies allowing users to search, create and manipulate computational resources (including data, documents, tools, people, devices, etc.) based on semantics (“meaning”, “intention”). It includes the computing technologies (e.g., artificial intelligence, natural language, software engineering, data and knowledge engineering, computer systems, signal processing, etc.), and their interactions, that may be used to extract or process computational content and descriptions. While some areas of Semantic Computing have appeared as isolated pieces in individual disciplines, Semantic Computing glues these pieces together into an integrated theme with synergetic interactions. It addresses not only the analysis and transformation of signals (e.g., pixels, words) into useful information, but also how such information can be accessed and synthesized.

The connection between content and the user can be made via (1) Analytics, which analyzes content with the goal of converting it to a description (semantics); (2) Semantic Description and Integration, which integrates content and semantics from multiple sources; (3) Applications, and (4) Semantic Interface, which attempt to interpret naturally expressed user intentions. The reverse connection converts descriptions of user intentions to create content of various sorts.

None of the existing I/UCRCs explicitly addresses the derivation and use of semantics for various types of contents. The Institute for Semantic Computing (ISC) has the mission to explore the full potential of Semantic Computing including basic research (as defined by the four scientific components) and applications (as defined by the application areas). The I/UCRC aims to substantiate the impacts of Semantic Computing based on the above to generalize the term “content” from text and “data” to include all types of resource such as communication, multimedia, software, devices and processes. For example, new technologies such as IoT (Internet of Things; GSMA estimates that the Internet will connect 24 billion devices by the year 2020 while many others including Cisco and Ericsson believe the number of devices will actually be much closer to the 50 billion mark).

A center is required to address the inherent complexity of the project to combine the strengths from universities, government laboratories, and industrial corporations. A center can achieve the “critical mass” to achieve multiple goals at the same time: perform the basic research, educate the students, and transform the outcomes into products that will create jobs and benefit the public. It is expected that the I/UCRC could (a) develop advanced semantic computing technologies; (2) transfer the technologies to its industrial partners for product development; (b) transfer the technologies to government laboratories for applications such as homeland security and national disaster prevention; and (c) train new scientists and engineers who can lead the “next” projects in the industry.

The outcomes of the planning grant include a planning workshop held at UCI on June 18 - 19, 2014. Attended by over 20 companies, much useful feedback was gathered on the proposed research projects and new project ideas were generated. A phase-1 proposal was submitted in September, 2014 by UCI and UCLA. The industry members consist of a good representation of large businesses (with more than 50% of the “shares” of the Center) including Ford, NEC, FXPAL and Ingrasys (designated by Foxconn which is one of the largest manufacturers). Small, new and younger industry partners (Expert System, Adaptive, Luminmax, DreamBox creation, and MyHero) introduce strong momentum and niches that may be substantiated by the influence of the larger and established companies. Projects are presented as multi-year research endeavors with the understanding that funding is allocated in 12-month installments, upon approval by the IAB.
